ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Hindi grammar, structure, better comprehension, better reading skills.
When I started taking Hindi at Yale, I couldn't speak at all! I have made a lot of progress thanks to Swapna Ji!
I learned better fluency in reading, writing, and speaking Hindi through extensive use and practice of all areas with real-life examples and support from Professor Sharma.
I learned how to read, write, and speak in Hindi.
analyzing and expressing thoughts on modern hindi texts.

I reviewed certain core grammar concept like the perfect tense and compound verbs. I got practice writing by summarizing videos and articles for assignments and some practice speaking in class. I also learned about certain cultural things like the history of India's oldest university and the story of a Bollywood film which has been lost.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Assignments should be posted earlier on. It was hard to keep track of them from announcements sent out by canvas message one or two days before class.
Swapna Ji is wonderful and attentive! The Hindi department needs WAY more money and staff.
I think more formal packet work could be added to the course to aid students with regimented spelling practice, but besides that I think the course is spot on!

We get to learn about interesting topics in India like precolonial Indian history and important issues like climate change while learning Hindi. One weakness is that the class is not structured very well.

the discussions were incredibly thoughtful and rewarding - all thanks to the amazing readings in class! the format is just wonderful.

as for improvements, one slight suggestion might be to include more creative writing prompts.

Swapnaji is really sweet and attentive. She wants students to learn and is always willing to answer questions. She's also always happy to go over concepts during office hours. There's also a diverse range of assignments, from presentations and group projects to essays, which makes the work more interesting. I also really appreciated that she takes time to correct the spelling/grammar of our assignments so we can learn. 

The major weakness is that Swapnaji doesn't really push us to speak our best during class and class time doesn't feel very interactive. A huge portion of classes were spent reading the articles we had for homework out loud. This is good reading practice but it's really easy to tune this out when you're not the one reading and doesn't really help improve speaking. I wish we spent more time actively having conversations and that Swapnaji asked more questions of people who are weaker so that they can get practice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend the course. I wish there was more discussion in class though.

If you know a bit of Hindi and can understand it (honestly if you can speak a bit too), it's a great way to learn the basics of grammar, writing, and reading! You will also improve your speaking and understanding skills.
Surely, I think this course fulfills the excitement of learning a language and becoming practiced in it in a manner that is not difficultly attained and fun!
I would recommend this class to students who want to advance their Hindi.
a hundred percent if youre interested in advancing your hindi language skills.

It depends. It's really easy to go through the motions and end up not improving much. If a student is coming from L4 and didn't have much Hindi background before Yale (like me), you need to take your own initiative to become more fluent. My vocabulary is better but Hindi grammar never fully clicked with me before and still, it's frustrating how many simple mistakes I make considering I'm technically "L5." 

If you're already comfortable with the essence of Hindi grammar/pronunciation and are looking for a (relatively relaxed) class to grow your vocabulary and practice, I think this course would be great.
